items.title: 'You are a very bad minister,' Conservative immigration critic says at tense committee meeting
items.summary_auto: Immigration Minister Lena Diab sparred with her Conservative critic at a tense House of Commons committee meeting Thursday as the two disagreed on everything from immigration levels and deporting non-citizen criminals to what kind of salad they prefer.

items.title: Canada's best- and worst-case scenarios for Friday's FIFA World Cup draw
Calgary-Banff rail idea submitted to Major Projects Office
items.summary_auto: A proposal for a hydrogen-powered passenger rail connecting Calgary and Banff has been submitted to the federal government in the hopes of having it fast-tracked.

items.title: Former national chief says AFN lawsuit to move ahead, settlement talks 'stonewalled'
Alberta legislation would change citizen referendum rules, restrict political party names
items.summary_auto: Bill 14, introduced Thursday by Justice Minister Mickey Amery, transfers powers from the chief electoral officer to the minister when deciding whether citizen petition initiatives should proceed. It also includes an amendment to discontinue any court proceeding brought by the chief electoral officer.

items.title: Ottawa to serve Stellantis with notice of default after receiving $220M then announcing U.S. production shift
Natural resources minister takes heat from B.C. chiefs over potential West Coast pipeline
items.summary_auto: Natural Resources Minister Tim Hodgson faced a failing grade and a cancelled speech at this week's Assembly of First Nations meeting as pushback grows among B.C. chiefs over the government's new  energy agreement  with Alberta.

items.title: Joly says feds will serve Stellantis with notice of default on funding contracts
items.summary_auto: The federal government is escalating its fight with automotive giant Stellantis over the company's decision to move some production to the U.S., despite receiving hundreds of millions of dollars in Canadian taxpayer incentives in recent years.

items.title: Where do First Nations rank on Carney’s priority list, regional chief asks ministers
items.summary_auto: Several members of Prime Minister Mark Carney’s cabinet addressed chiefs and delegates at the AFN Special Chiefs Assembly in Ottawa on Thursday. Chiefs had the opportunity to ask the ministers about First Nations priorities, including major projects and infrastructure, child welfare and community safety.

items.title: Bloc says Liberals 'fear backlash' from removing religious exemptions in hate speech law
Province pauses AI commercial from N.B. Liquor after negative reception
items.summary_auto: N.B. Liquor is catching enough heat for a holiday video campaign made with artificial intelligence that a government minister has directed the Crown corporation to take the ad down.

items.title: Children’s hospitals in Canada face flood of flu visits as doctors urge families to get vaccinated
Indigenous friendship centres want clarity on future federal funding
items.summary_auto: The president for the National Association of Friendship Centres says uncertainty around how much money they will have to work with next year is raising alarms for the centres that provide services for Indigenous people in urban areas.

items.title: Josh Naylor, who starred after trade to Mariners, named top Canadian in MLB for 2025
items.summary_auto: Seattle Mariners first baseman Josh Naylor of Mississauga, Ont., has won the 2025 Tip O'Neill Award, presented annually by the Canadian Baseball Hall of Fame to the top Canadian player in Major League Baseball.

items.title: B.C. police watchdog clears officers in shooting death of 15-year-old in Surrey
items.summary_auto: The Independent Investigations Office of B.C. says there are not reasonable grounds to believe an officer committed any offence in the shooting death of a 15-year-old in Surrey earlier this year.

items.title: At least 4 countries pull out of 2026 Eurovision contest as Israel's participation sows discord
items.summary_auto: Spain and the Netherlands say they are pulling out of next year's Eurovision Song Contest as Israel's participation roils the competition.

items.title: Debates commission looking at changes after 'perfect storm' clouded last leaders' showdown
items.summary_auto: The head of Canada's Leaders' Debates Commission says the independent body should stop organizing post-debate news conferences and will make changes to how it decides what leaders to invite after this spring's leadership debate was surrounded by controversy.

items.title: Manitoba updates asbestos regulations, including workers' certification, employer registration
items.summary_auto: Manitoba is updating its regulations governing the handling of asbestos to protect workers from dangerous exposure to the material, the leading cause of work-place related deaths in the province, the government says.

items.title: Alberta Health Services CEO on leave of absence, province confirms
items.summary_auto: Eleven months ago, Andre Tremblay was appointed top executive and sole director of AHS after the ouster of both the entire board and then-CEO Athana Mentzelopoulos.

items.title: Ottawa begins to consider the possibility of a Quebec referendum
items.summary_auto: The Parti Québécois's dominance in the polls for nearly two years and its leader Paul St-Pierre Plamondon's promise to hold a referendum on Quebec sovereignty during his first term have reverberated all the way to Ottawa.

items.title: Talks break off between Quebec and family doctors, only weeks before reforms set to take effect
items.summary_auto: Negotiations between the Quebec government and family doctors have collapsed again, just weeks before controversial reforms take effect that doctors warn will force them to close their clinics — or leave the province altogether.

items.title: 2 Alberta cabinet ministers say money a key factor in using Charter override on teachers
items.summary_auto: Two Alberta cabinet ministers say money was a key factor in the United Conservative government's decision to use the Charter's notwithstanding clause to override teachers' rights and shut down a provincewide strike.

items.title: Brett Gallant, doing curling double duty at Olympics, will provide valuable insight to Canada's teams
items.summary_auto: Besides giving curlers two Olympic medal chances, doing double duty provides teams valuable insight into the ice, rocks and conditions in game scenarios.

items.title: Manitoba to sell shelved U.S. booze with revenue going to holiday charities: premier
items.summary_auto: Manitoba is pulling out a million dollars worth of U.S.-made alcohol it shelved months ago amid the tumultuous trade war with the U.S., with plans of now selling the liquor ahead of Christmas and sending the proceeds to holiday charities.

items.title: Russia blocks Roblox, Apple's FaceTime amid growing rebuke of foreign tech platforms
items.summary_auto: Russia has blocked Apple's video-calling app FaceTime, the state communications watchdog said Thursday, just a day after blocking the children's gaming platform Roblox.

items.title: FBI arrest Virginia man accused of planting pipe bombs in Washington in 2021
items.summary_auto: The FBI arrested a 30-year-old Virginia man and charged him with planting a pair of pipe bombs in Washington the night before the January 6, 2021, assault on the U.S. Capitol, officials said on Thursday.

items.title: Carney to meet Trump on sidelines of FIFA event, as U.S. president threatens to leave trade agreement
As cleanup costs mount, oilpatch may be forced to pay deposit before drilling new wells
items.summary_auto: Alberta’s premier is floating the idea of making oil and gas companies pay a deposit before they can drill a new well, as the provincial government tries to tackle the large number of old oil and gas wells which require cleanup.

items.title: Putin says Russia will take Donbas by force if it's not ceded by Ukraine
items.summary_auto: President Vladimir Putin said in an interview published on Thursday that Russia would take full control of Ukraine's Donbas region by force unless Ukrainian forces withdraw — something Kyiv has flatly rejected.

items.title: Trump proposes slashing fuel economy rules in boost for gas vehicles
items.summary_auto:
Ford's CEO supports aligning standards with market realities, while an environmental group criticizes rollback for increasing 
costs at the pump.

items.title: 'It would be wrong': Why Richmond, B.C., residents weren't told about First Nation's claim to title
items.summary_auto: Since a B.C. Supreme Court judge ruled earlier this year that Aboriginal title coexists alongside fee simple title on around 125 privately-held parcels of land in Richmond, a question has hung over the case: why didn't the private landowners know the title to their property was up for debate?

items.title: ​'A really big deal': ​Sask. chess player is two steps away from becoming a grandmaster
items.summary_auto: Omid Khaledi recently reached the rank of FIDE master with the International Chess Federation, or FIDE, which is just two steps below becoming a grandmaster.

items.title: Chain restaurants are out. Restaurant groups are in
items.summary_auto: A peek behind the curtain at how big players in the restaurant industry, who own multiple, seemingly independent restaurants, leverage better buying power as a way to survive post-COVID.

items.title: Israel identifies body of returned hostage as Thai national
items.summary_auto: Israel has identified the remains of the hostage it received from Hamas on Wednesday as Thai agricultural worker Sudthisak Rinthalak, the prime minister's office said on Thursday.

items.title: Windsor housing non-profit director fired after allegations of $500K in unauthorized pay hikes for family
items.summary_auto: Court documents filed by LSCDG obtained by CBC News show accusations of financial misconduct totalling $3 million by the Labour Sponsored Community Development Group's former executive director Anna Angelidis and two administrators she supervised: her sons Jim and Danny.

items.title: Food prices could increase in 2026, with meat leading the way, say Dalhousie researchers
items.summary_auto: Food prices in Canada could increase by four to six per cent next year, largely led by pricier meat products, according to a forecast by researchers at Dalhousie University.

items.title: Trade tensions temporarily on backburner as PM visits Washington for FIFA celebration
items.summary_auto: Though Prime Minister Mark Carney’s upcoming trip to the U.S. is all about FIFA soccer, it’s hard to overlook the political tensions ahead of the upcoming review of the Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement. If there’s an opportunity to nudge Canada-U.S. relations in a more positive direction, insiders suggest Carney should take it.

items.title: Trump offered Putin a tactical victory in Ukraine. It wasn’t enough
items.summary_auto: The Kremlin has again rejected U.S. President Donald Trump's latest proposals to end the war in Ukraine. While Trump has tried to entice Russian President Vladimir Putin with offers of Ukrainian territory and lucrative future commercial contracts, Putin's goal of subjugating Ukraine isn't something Trump can put on the table.

items.title: Transforming F1: How female and Gen Z fandom is shaping the sport’s future
items.summary_auto: In Canada and the U.S., F1 has gone from niche motorsport to mainstream obsession in just a few years. It’s a shift driven by a new wave of fans who are remaking the sport's social media landscape and driving the call for representation.

items.title: Meta has begun shutting down kids' social media in Australia. The world is watching to see how it unfolds
items.summary_auto: As platforms like Instagram, TikTok, Snapchat and YouTube begin to comply with Australia's new landmark law banning social media for those under 16, Aussie youth are now seeing pop-ups about their accounts being deactivated or put on hold. Is there a potential for ripple effects in Canada?

items.title: How singing in a choir might help people find their voices after a stroke
items.summary_auto: A randomized controlled trial involving 12 weekly choir sessions for participants who have developed aphasia from strokes, aims to find out if singing together helps them re-gain their ability to speak and write.

items.title: Your favourite TV shows are changing how episodes are released. Is appointment viewing back?
items.summary_auto: From hit dramas like Stranger Things and The Summer I Turned Pretty, to attention grabbing reality shows, many shows on streaming platforms that made their name on binge watching are now releasing episodes weekly or in bite-sized chunks. Experts say the format and social factors are driving some fans to catch episodes when they air, though with more flexibility than broadcast TV allows.
